items.title: After Rocket Attack, an Israeli City Seems Resigned to More in the Future
items.abstract: Intense fighting with Gaza has heightened concerns about safety in Rishon LeZion and seems to have renewed the sentiment among residents of the unlikeliness of a long-term solution in their lifetimes.

items.title: A Hidden Warrior in the Park
items.abstract: Metropolitan Diary: A new acquaintance finds a bronze statue of an American Indian in a trash can in Carl Schurz Park.

items.title: Big City, Crazy Killer, Loner Cop
items.abstract: In Warren Ellis’s “Gun Machine” a murderous psychopath who believes he is a resident of pre-colonial Manhattan is tracked by a messy, isolated police detective.

items.title: Hurricane Cost City at Least $154 Million in Overtime
items.abstract: Eighty-one percent of the total went to the Police and Sanitation Departments alone, according to a report released Friday by the Independent Budget Office.

items.title: Ada Louise Huxtable, Champion of Livable Architecture, Dies at 91
items.abstract: Ms. Huxtable pioneered modern architectural criticism in The New York Times, celebrating buildings that respected human dignity and civic history.

items.title: Review: Bank on the Seafood at Fish Urban Dining in Ridgewood
items.abstract: Situated in a former Bank of America branch on East Ridgewood Avenue, the seafood restaurant has 30-foot ceilings, huge chandeliers and extends into what was the vault.

items.title: ‘Design Thinking’ for a Better You
items.abstract: A strategy called “design thinking” has helped numerous entrepreneurs and engineers develop successful new products and businesses. But can design thinking help you create healthful habits?

items.title: Municipal Identification Card Program Offers Free Cultural Benefits
items.abstract: Enrollment in the program includes free annual memberships to 40 institutions. Here’s a borough-by-borough list of highlights.

items.title: New York City
items.abstract: New books include Gerard Koeppel’s “City on a Grid: How New York Became New York.”
keywords: City on a Grid: How New York Became New York (Book)
Fun City: John Lindsay, Joe Namath, and How Sports Saved New York in the 1960s (Book)
The Con Men: Hustling in New York City (Book)

items.title: California Beach City Enlists Private Partner to Rejuvenate Pier
items.abstract: Redondo Beach, once a major tourist destination, no longer attracts crowds of visitors. A $250 million public-private project to redevelop its faded waterfront aims to change that.

items.title: In High-Tech Cities, No More Potholes, but What About Privacy?
items.abstract: Cities, including some far from the coasts, are vying to use technology to guide services. But the race toward “smart cities” is raising privacy worries.

items.title: Traffic Deaths in New York City Drop to 200, a Record Low
items.abstract: Fewer people were killed last year in vehicle crashes, a sign that Mayor Bill de Blasio’s Vision Zero plan is working. But pedestrian deaths increased.

items.title: Mexico City as the Director of ‘Roma’ Remembers It (and Hears It)
items.abstract: Alfonso Cuarón revisits the sights and sounds of the neighborhood that inspired his critically acclaimed film.

items.title: How Paparazzi Dogs and Rabbitgirl Conquered New York City Streets
items.abstract: Going around the traditional gatekeepers, Gillie and Marc Schattner of Australia have become the city’s most prolific creators of public art.

items.title: What’s Coming in New York Real Estate in 2019
items.abstract: An already soft market will get another 20,000 new apartments, making it an even stronger buyer’s and renter’s market.

items.title: Nashville Finds Opportunity in the Hole a Bomber Left in the Heart of the City
items.abstract: Since the explosion last Christmas, the city has grappled with how rebuilding will fit into its larger ambitions of transforming downtown. The hope is to draw more than just tourists.

items.title: Put a Female Statue on a Vacant Pedestal? An Italian City Says Not So Fast.
items.abstract: In Padua, Italy, a proposal to include a female philosopher in a monument whose 78 sculptures are all men has spurred debate.

items.title: ‘American Urbanist,’ a Well-Timed Biography of a Man Who Reshaped City Life
items.abstract: Richard K. Rein’s book tells the story of William H. Whyte, a sociologist who wrote “The Organization Man” and helped to rethink how cities look and feel.
keywords: American Urbanist: How William H Whyte's Unconventional Wisdom Reshaped Public Life (Book)

items.title: Edward Kirkland, Who Helped Preserve Historic Chelsea, Dies at 96
items.abstract: He played a less public but powerful role in creating the High Line, Hudson River Park and landmark districts in the Manhattan neighborhood.

items.title: Mexico City’s Newfound Status: A Skateboarder’s Paradise
items.abstract: With improved accessibility and support from the government, skateboarding schools, stores and a diverse social scene have taken flight.
